newsitem.title: USA: U.S. High Court grants Honeywell appeal vs Litton.
newsitem.headline: U.S. High Court grants Honeywell appeal vs Litton.

text.p: The U.S. Supreme Court Monday granted Honeywell Inc's appeal and set aside a ruling that reinstated a jury verdict of patent infringement liability in a dispute with Litton Industries Inc.

The ruling by a federal appeals court called for a new trial on the amount of damages Litton should be awarded. Litton has been seeking $1.96 billion in damages from Honeywell as part of the legal battle that dates back to 1990.
Litton has charged that Honeywell had willfully infringed on a Litton patent for developing a laser gyroscope navigation and guidance system.
The high court set aside the appeals court decision and sent the case back for further consideration in view of a Supreme Court ruling earlier this month.
The Supreme court in that ruling upheld a key part of patent law that makes it easier for patent holders to protect their inventions from similar ideas.

After a lengthy trial in 1993, a federal jury awarded Litton $1.2 billion. But U.S. District Judge Mariana Pfaelzer in Los Angeles threw out the award, determining as a matter of law that Honeywell did not infringe Litton's patent.
But the appeals court in July reinstated the jury's verdict of patent infringement. It refused to reinstate the jury's $1.2 billion award and ordered a new trial to determine damages.
Honeywell appealed to the Supreme Court, saying the appeals court decision was wrong in finding patent infringement. The patent at issue in the case will expire in 1998.
